title: State of the world's plants and fungi report: 3 in 4 undescribed plant species already threatened with extinction
description: RBG Kew's fifth State of the World's report, published today, lays out the current condition of the world's plants and fungi globally. Based on the work of 200 international researchers and covering the content of more than 25 cutting-edge scientific papers in its 11 chapters, the new report examines global drivers and patterns of biodiversity as well as critical knowledge gaps and how to address them.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Skeletal remains debunk myth surrounding 1918 flu pandemic
description: Look back at the chronicle of global pandemics, and the flu pandemic of 1918 stands out as an anomaly for one reason: According to the history books, it struck healthy adults in their prime just as often, if not more so, than the weak or sickly.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A new mineral, kanatzidisite, recognizes scientist's decades of contributions to chalcogenide chemistry
description: What do Mozart, Christopher Columbus and J.P. Morgan have in common? It turns out they all have minerals named after them. A new member of this exclusive club has recently been inducted: Mercouri Kanatzidis, materials scientist at the U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE) Argonne National Laboratory and professor at Northwestern University.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Diversity in government contracts still falls short of equal opportunity for disadvantaged firms
description: When it comes to government contracts, diversity doesn't necessarily translate into equity, according to a University of Michigan study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists find the sounds beneath our feet are fingerprints of rock stability
description: If you could sink through the Earth's crust, you might hear, with a carefully tuned ear, a cacophany of booms and crackles along the way. The fissures, pores, and defects running through rocks are like strings that resonate when pressed and stressed. And as a team of MIT geologists has found, the rhythm and pace of these sounds can tell you something about the depth and strength of the rocks around you.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Archaeologists discover 5,000-year-old wine at the tomb of Meret-Neith in Abydos
description: A German-Austrian team led by archaeologist Christiana Köhler from the University of Vienna is investigating the tomb of Queen Meret-Neith in Abydos, Egypt. She was the most powerful woman in the period around 3,000 BC. Recent excavations prove her special historical significance: the researchers found 5,000-year-old wine and other grave goods. This fuels speculation that Meret-Neith was the first pharaoh of ancient Egypt and predecessor of the later Queen Hatshepsut.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mushroom-derived materials could offer benefits for developing nations in Africa
description: A research team from the University of Bristol has suggested that mycelium composites could offer a sustainable alternative to traditional building materials and help address socio-economic and environmental challenges in Africa.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 1 in 5 prisoners in the Netherlands is overlooked by professionals, says researcher
description: Prisoners deserve better professional support when preparing to return to society. Ph.D. candidate Amanda Pasma says, "You can't imprison everyone for life. Society will have to give prisoners a second chance."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: How much of a threat is the spotted lanternfly?
description: It might sport some Terp colors, but a new invasive species that's just been found on campus isn't worth cheering for.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New fish species found in the Great Barrier Reef
description: At a time when marine life is disappearing from the world's oceans, researchers are celebrating the discovery of a new species of coral reef fish in the southern waters of the Great Barrier Reef.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Increase in forest fires may damage the crucial ozone layer
description: All particles that reach the atmosphere cause different chemical reactions. Particles come partly from natural sources such as volcanic eruptions and forest fires, and partly from pollution and emissions. Aerosol researcher Johan Friberg studies particles at high altitudes. He fears that the global increase in forest fires could have a significant impact on the ozone layer.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Where do rehabbed turtles go?
description: When a wild turtle recovers from an accident and is released back into the wild, what happens next? A new study from North Carolina State University reveals that finding those answers can often be just as challenging as saving the turtle itself.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researcher: Today's white working-class young men who turn to racist violence are part of a long, sad American history
description: In recent years, the United States has seen a surge of white supremacist mass shootings against racial minorities. While not always the case, mass shooters tend to be young white men.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Building environmental policy on America's support for a clean environment
description: Listening to some politicos on the campaign trail, it's easy to assume that most Americans are against protecting the environment and that government should simply let the market regulate itself. For decades the Gallup poll has posed a question about the false trade-off between economic growth and environmental protection.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Microalgae: An environmentally friendly and healthy alternative to fish
description: The volunteers participating in a tasting study at the University of Hohenheim tested a new food: microalgae. The taste is reminiscent of fish and the recipe is still being fine-tuned. From a nutritional point of view, the single-cell organisms are veritable all-rounders. Just like marine fish, they are a source of important omega-3 fatty acids and high levels of protein, dietary fiber, vitamins, and carotenoids.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: A 'ring of fire' eclipse is coming. Here's how to watch
description: At about 10:30 a.m. Mountain Time on Saturday, Oct. 14, the moon will pass in front of the sun above much of the western U.S., creating a blazing "ring of fire" in the sky.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study explores how risk tolerance changes around payday
description: People living in poverty often struggle from payday to payday. Those who receive government assistance, such as welfare or pensions, must manage scarce resources to make ends meet until the next payment. Researchers from Kobe University, the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research, Toyo University, and Simon Fraser University have studied how people's willingness to take risks changes before and after payday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Unifying matter, energy and consciousness: Applying physics to a thorny topic
description: With the rise of brain-interface technology and artificial intelligence that can imitate brain functions, understanding the nature of consciousness and how it interacts with reality is not just an age-old philosophical question but also a salient challenge for humanity.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Prescription opioid companies increased marketing after Purdue Pharma lawsuit, study shows
description: Purdue Pharma is inextricably linked with the opioid crisis.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Newly-discovered 'margarita snails' from the Florida Keys
description: The "Margaritaville" in Jimmy Buffett's famous song isn't a real place, but it's long been associated with the Florida Keys. This string of tropical islands is home to the only living coral barrier reef in the continental US, along with many animals found nowhere else in the world. One of them is a newly-discovered, bright yellow snail, named in honor of Margaritaville. The lemon- (or, key-lime-) colored snail, along with its lime-green cousin from Belize, is the subject of a study published in the journal PeerJ.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hubble's multi-wavelength view of recently released Webb image
description: Patches of bright pink and wisps of dark red paint the foreground of this new NASA Hubble Space Telescope image. NGC 5068 is a barred spiral galaxy with thousands of star-forming regions and large quantities of interstellar dust. First discovered by British astronomer William Herschel in 1785, NGC 5068 sits in the southern region of the constellation Virgo and is around 20 million light-years away. Astronomers estimate the galaxy is 45,000 light-years in diameter.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Vega flight takes satellites to space
description: Today (Oct. 10) at 22:36 local time (02:36 BST, 03:36 CEST) the 23rd Vega flight saw its two main satellites launched and released into Earth orbit. The rocket's main passengers were the Earth observing THEOS-2 satellite and the meteorological satellite Triton.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Coolant leaked from Russian part of ISS, crew safe: Roscosmos
description: Liquid has leaked from the Russian portion of the International Space Station but the crew are not in any danger, the Russian space agency Roscosmos said on Monday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: How foreign investment in US land affects food security
description: David Ortega, faculty laureate and associate professor in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources, provided expert testimony to the United States Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry's hearing on foreign investment in U.S. agriculture on Wednesday, Sept. 27. The committee is chaired by U.S. Senator Debbie Stabenow of Michigan. Ortega answers questions about his testimony.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bear that charged two boys in Colorado Springs euthanized
description: A bear that charged two boys in a Colorado Springs open space was euthanized, and its cubs tranquilized, Colorado Parks and Wildlife officials announced Friday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Night owls may earn less than early birds: Study reveals connections between circadian rhythm and income level
description: Researchers from the University of Oulu, Finland, have uncovered a link between internal circadian rhythm and income levels. According to the study, now published in Economics & Human Biology, individuals who tend to be more active in the evening hours (night owls) also tend to exhibit characteristics that are associated with lower income. This relationship was mainly observed for men in the middle-aged study sample.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Colorado secures the first wolves for reintroduction from Oregon
description: Oregon will provide the first gray wolves for Colorado's voter-mandated reintroduction of the species, wildlife officials announced Friday after a months-long search for a state willing to provide the canine before a Dec. 31 deadline.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Planned launch has SpaceX back on task on Space Coast
description: SpaceX handed over the Space Coast spotlight for a short time last week with United Launch Alliance managing an Atlas V liftoff for Amazon, but Elon Musk's company is back to the business of sticking more of its Starlink satellites into orbit.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ancient Maya reservoirs offer lessons for today's water crises
description: According to a new paper, ancient Maya reservoirs, which used aquatic plants to filter and clean the water, "can serve as archetypes for natural, sustainable water systems to address future water needs."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate-driven extreme heat may make parts of Earth too hot for humans
description: If global temperatures increase by 1° Celsius (C) or more than current levels, each year billions of people will be exposed to heat and humidity so extreme they will be unable to naturally cool themselves, according to interdisciplinary research from the Penn State College of Health and Human Development, Purdue University College of Sciences and Purdue Institute for a Sustainable Future.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Long-term lizard study challenges the rules of evolutionary biology
description: Charles Darwin said that evolution was constantly happening, causing animals to adapt for survival. But many of his contemporaries disagreed. If evolution is always causing things to change, they asked, then how is it that two fossils from the same species, found in the same location, can look identical despite being 50 million years apart in age?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nature is inventive—the same substance is produced differently by plants
description: Maize plants form special compounds derived from indole, the so-called benzoxazinoids. They are considered ecologically important because they act against a wide range of herbivores and reduce their feeding. Benzoxazinoids also exhibit antimicrobial properties and are thought to be involved in mediating plant-plant interactions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Space weather disrupts nocturnal bird migration, study finds
description: It's well-known that birds and other animals rely on Earth's magnetic field for long-distance navigation during seasonal migrations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Atlas V launches from Cape Canaveral with prototype Amazon satellites
description: A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket climbed through the Space Coast skies carrying a pair of prototype satellites to orbit on the first of what's planned to be dozens of launches for Amazon.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Spatial sorting' dominated bug evolution after Hurricane Harvey flooding, study shows
description: With species the world over on the move due to climate change, a unique experiment in the wake of 2017's Hurricane Harvey has revealed a way that species can instantly evolve when they move in response to a climate catastrophe.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: When rentals go wrong: Study explores sharing economy and ways to boost good customer behavior
description: Consumers are increasingly paying for temporary access to products and services through companies like Rent the Runway, Netflix, Airbnb, and Uber—creating an "access-based industry" that's expected to grow to $335 billion by 2025. But, in exchange for low prices, there's an additional cost to customers in terms of their time and effort.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study finds tropical ecosystems more reliant on emerging aquatic insects, potentially at greater risk
description: A team of researchers from Queen Mary University of London and the University of Campinas in Brazil has found that tropical forest ecosystems are more reliant on aquatic insects than temperate forest ecosystems and are therefore more vulnerable to disruptions to the links between land and water.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How phytochemical diversity affects herbivore damage in a tropical tree community
description: Recent advances in metabolomics are improving our understanding of the ecological impacts of plant chemical diversity. However, few studies have examined how phytochemical diversity affects herbivore damage at the community scale in tropical tree communities.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Savoring the sweetness: Unraveling pineapple's SWEET10 as a glucose transporter
description: Researchers from Professor Yuan Qin's group at Guangxi University have now harnessed cutting-edge AlphaFold technology to unveil the hidden secrets of sugar transporter proteins, known as SWEET (Sugars Will Eventually be Exported Transporters).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Forest polyploid breeding group analyzes the genetic regulatory network of poplar leaf development
description: As an important source organ, leaves are the main site of photosynthesis in plants, and analyzing the developmental process of leaves can help to improve the photosynthetic assimilation capacity of plants.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Starlinks are easily detected by radio telescopes
description: Radio astronomy and satellite communication have a long common history. Advances made in one field have benefitted the other, and our modern era of spacecraft and mobile internet is a product of this partnership. But there are times when the goals of radio astronomy and the goals of communication satellites are in opposition. This is most clearly seen in the development of satellite constellations such as Starlink.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Astronomers discover M87's jet is triggering novae
description: Everyone loves a good mystery, and astronomers have just uncovered a new one in a nearby supermassive galaxy called M87. Like most galaxies, M87 regularly plays host to a smattering of stellar explosions called novae, each the result of a star stealing material from a neighbor.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Here's what it would take to see a black hole's photon ring
description: Supermassive black holes are elusive creatures. Massive gravitational beasts that can power immensely bright quasars, or can lurk quietly among the bright stars of a galactic core. We mostly study them indirectly through their bright accretion disks or powerful jets of plasma they create, but we have been able to observe them more directly, such as our images of M87* and Sag A*.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's OSIRIS-REx asteroid sample curation steps closer to final reveal
description: As the astromaterials curation team at NASA's Johnson Space Center continues to collect the bonus asteroid Bennu particles located outside the OSIRIS-REx TAGSAM (Touch-and-Go Sample Acquisition Mechanism) head, they've also completed additional steps toward disassembly and reveal of the bulk asteroid sample inside the head.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The largest dam removal in history stirs hopes of restoring California tribes' way of life
description: At first, the dead floated downstream a few at a time. Then they came by the hundreds, and then the thousands.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Coral researchers see 'mass mortality' amid Florida Reef bleaching crisis
description: Battered by heat, washed out to a bleached, white hue and ravaged by disease, corals offshore of Key Largo, Florida, used what little energy they had left to spawn the next generation that could save their populations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Record heat unleashes deadly floods from New York to Libya
description: Extreme heat is usually associated with drought and wildfires. But across five continents this year, it's also unleashed a different kind of disaster: deadly flooding.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: California drought status: Stubborn conditions remain after a wet water year
description: California is 99.93% drought-free, according to an update from the U.S. Drought Monitor. But Del Norte County reentered drought status in August after having been drought-free since January.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New foods can go from yucky to yummy as people's perceptions evolve
description: Bugs, microalgae and bacteria are emerging as healthy and sustainable alternatives to traditional proteins.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study finds that the Gulf Stream is warming and shifting closer to shore
description: The Gulf Stream is intrinsic to the global climate system, bringing warm waters from the Caribbean up the East Coast of the United States. As it flows along the coast and then across the Atlantic Ocean, this powerful ocean current influences weather patterns and storms, and it carries heat from the tropics to higher latitudes as part of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Annular distribution of SiC2 in circumstellar envelopes of carbon-rich asymptotic giant branch stars
description: The circumstellar envelopes (CSE) of asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars contain a large number of molecules, which account for about one-third of all molecules discovered in interstellar space.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop nonlinear optical crystals by unusual cationic substitution strategy
description: An ideal infrared (IR) nonlinear optical (NLO) crystal must have the advantages of a wide transmittance range, impressive laser-induced damage threshold (LIDT), sufficient birefringence index, bulk single-crystal form, and physicochemical stability.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Meta-learning helps to estimate oceanic barrier layer structure
description: The oceanic barrier layer is situated between the base of the ocean's density mixed layer and the top of the isothermal layer, with its thickness fluctuations directly influencing the ocean's vertical mixing process. Changes in the barrier layer impact the transport of heat and salinity within the ocean, subsequently affecting regional weather and climate patterns.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers reveal dust source on Tibetan Plateau
description: Dust deposited on a glacier's surface can reduce the albedo of the ice and increase absorption efficiency of solar radiation, which has a significant impact on glacier melting and global climate change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study reveals relationship between spatiotemporal variations of freezing index and permafrost degradation
description: The freezing index (FI) is a crucial factor for calculating the temporal and spatial distribution of permafrost and the thickness of the active layer in a permafrost region. Understanding the variation in thermal conditions of the permafrost active layer is significant for investigating both the spatial and temporal distribution of permafrost as well as its degradation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists clone novel gene responsible for glufosinate resistance in rice
description: Researchers have cloned a novel gene responsible for glufosinate resistance in rice and conducted in-depth analysis of its functional characteristics. The team was led by Prof. Wu Yuejin from Hefei Institutes of Physical Science (HFIPS) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Discovery of half-million-year-old wooden structure shows we're wrong to underestimate our ancient relatives
description: To most people, complex technologies separate modern humans from their ancestors who lived in the Stone Age, thousands or hundreds of thousands of years ago. In today's fast changing world, older technologies, even those from a few years ago, are often described dismissively as "Stone Age."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ecowas rules to protect pastoralists discourage investments in modern livestock farming, says researcher
description: A common sight around west Africa is to see cattle grazing freely, even in major cities, on highways and in airports.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers realize orientation control of cMOF nanofilms
description: Researchers from the Institute of Process Engineering (IPE) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and Kyoto University have proposed a strategy to grow "face-on" and "edge-on" conductive metal-organic frameworks (cMOF) nanofilms on substrates by controlling the "stand-up" behaviors of ligands on various surfaces to overcome the difficulty in the orientation control of such films.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The Atlantic Ocean's major current system is slowing down—but a 21st century collapse is unlikely
description: Whether the water at your local beach is being roiled by nasty weather or is a perfectly calm expanse of blue, there's always a great deal going on under the surface. The ocean is composed of various currents and water masses; those currents flow around the world through what is called thermohaline circulation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Opinion: China's youth unemployment problem has become a crisis we can no longer ignore
description: Youth unemployment is a global problem, but in China the rate—21.3%—is particularly alarming, not just because it's high, but because it could affect other economies and geopolitical relations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: There are 750 unidentified human remains in Australia. Could your DNA help solve one of these cold cases?
description: Yesterday it was announced the Australian Federal Police (AFP) National DNA Program for Unidentified and Missing Persons used advanced DNA technology to assist South Australia Police resolve a 40-year-old missing persons case.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Why do so few women take on scientific careers?
description: There were around 8 billion human beings in 2022, 50% of them women. Although there are as many women as men, the former continue to be underrepresented in science.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research team clarifies molecular mechanisms of fungal infections
description: Fungal infections pose a threat to humans, animals and plants, and can have serious consequences. Together with colleagues from Frankfurt/Main and Aachen, a research team from Heinrich Heine University Düsseldorf (HHU) has now clarified an important mechanism in how such infections are regulated at molecular level. In Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), they describe how this discovery may lead to the development of new antifungal agents.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New observations of flares from distant star could help in search for habitable planets
description: Astrophysicists have used the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) to take a close look at a volatile star.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Claudia Goldin: Nobel-winning sleuth of the gender pay gap
description: Claudia Goldin has long thought of herself as a kind of detective within economics, employing tools across academic disciplines in a quest to examine how women fit into the workforce.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New findings facilitate solar storm forecasting based on dimming of sun's corona
description: Researchers have developed new methods for using coronal dimmings observed in the solar corona for early diagnosis of powerful bursts of plasma from the sun.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Vacuum cleaner-effect in fungi can hold nanoplastics at bay
description: Using micro-engineered soil models, researchers at Lund University in Sweden have investigated the effect of tiny polystyrene particles on bacteria and fungi. While these nanoplastics reduced both bacterial and fungal growth, the fungus actually managed to "clean up" their surroundings, thereby easing the effect of the plastics. Their work has been published in Science of The Total Environment.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bacteria opt for the best price-to-quality ratio to predict the future
description: Predicting the future can be a matter of life or death. Just think, every time you cross the street, you predict whether this is possible without being run over. Experiments show that even single-celled organisms such as bacteria can predict the future. The better bacteria can predict changes in their environment, the greater their chances of survival.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Models suggest interlinking rivers in India to meet water demand may adversely impact monsoon rainfall amounts
description: A team of civil engineers and meteorologists at the Indian Institute of Technology, working with colleagues from the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology and the University of Hyderabad, has found, via modeling, that a plan to interlink rivers in India to capture rain runoff could inadvertently have a negative impact on the amount and location of monsoon rainfall.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Plate tectonic surprise: Geologist unexpectedly finds remnants of a lost mega-plate
description: Utrecht University geologist Suzanna van de Lagemaat has reconstructed a massive and previously unknown tectonic plate that was once one-quarter the size of the Pacific Ocean. Her colleagues in Utrecht had predicted its existence over 10 years ago based on fragments of old tectonic plates found deep in the Earth's mantle. Van de Lagemaat reconstructed lost plates through field research and detailed investigations of the mountain belts of Japan, Borneo, the Philippines, New Guinea, and New Zealand.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: DREAM tool for gene therapies uses 'locally sourced' components
description: Sourcing some materials closer to home may be a good practice not only in the produce aisle but also the synthetic biology lab.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New analytical tool improves genetic analysis and research accuracy
description: Rutgers researchers have developed an analytical tool for spotting and omitting stray DNA and RNA that contaminate genetic analyses of single-celled organisms.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Glacial lake outburst floods in Alaska and the Himalayas show evolving hazards in a warming world
description: In August 2023, residents of Juneau, Alaska, watched as the Mendenhall River swelled to historic levels in a matter of hours. The rushing water undercut the riverbank and swallowed whole stands of trees and multiple buildings.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists gain powerful tool to scrutinize changing US weather patterns
description: An extraordinary new dataset of high-resolution weather simulations that span more than four decades over the continental United States is now available to the Earth system science community.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Epigenetic regulator MOF drives mitochondrial metabolism, new study shows
description: The intricate control of cellular metabolism relies on the coordinated and harmonious interplay between the nucleus and mitochondria. On the one hand, mitochondria are the hub for the production of essential metabolites, which aside from being required to meet the energy demands of the cell, also serve as the building blocks for constructing both genetic and epigenetic landscapes in the nucleus. On the other hand, the majority of mitochondrial metabolic enzymes are encoded by the nuclear genome, making the function of these two organelles highly interdependent on one another.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers reveal mechanism of efficient upconversion in two-dimensional perovskite
description: Recently, a research team led by Prof. Liu Xinfeng from the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology (NCNST) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) reported the efficient phonon-assisted upconversion luminescence in a quasi-two-dimensional perovskite system.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating a recently discovered Arabian Partridge population in Saudi Arabia's Harrat Uwayrid Biosphere Reserve
description: Forming a land bridge between Asia, Europe and Africa, the Arabian Desert hosts a distinctive wildlife community adapted to extreme conditions. Many of the rare, threatened and endemic species inhabiting this region have received little study or conservation attention due to the challenges of conducting fieldwork in this region's harsh climate and topography.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: An ultra-mild and functional-group tolerant method to produce arynes
description: Researchers at Colorado State University are part of a collaborative study with Oxford University that has developed an ultra-mild and functional-group tolerant method to produce arynes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Combining a bulky chain with a stable polymer to enhance liquid crystal performance
description: From laptop screens to navigation systems, liquid crystals are ubiquitous in modern life. These materials flow like liquids, but their molecules align with one another in a way that resembles the orientational order of a crystal. Electrically switching between different molecular orientations—or phases—in a liquid crystal changes how the material transmits light, hence their use/utility in visual displays.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Could a new law of physics support the idea we're living in a computer simulation?
description: A University of Portsmouth physicist has explored whether a new law of physics could support the much-debated theory that we are simply characters in an advanced virtual world.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hybridization of Atlantic puffins in the Arctic coincides with 20th-century climate change
description: A team of ecologists and evolutionary scientists at the University of Oslo, working with colleagues from the Norwegian Institute for Nature Research, the Norwegian Polar Institute, the Swedish Museum of Natural History, and the American Museum of Natural History, has found that two subspecies of Atlantic puffin that historically have lived far apart began intermingling over the past century, resulting in the development of a new hybrid puffin species.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Darwin or Kimura? Natural selection or pure chance? New literature review aims to clarify a heated debate
description: Some of nature's mysteries have kept scientists busy for decades—for example, the processes that drive evolution. The question of whether certain differences between and within species are caused by natural selection or by chance processes divides evolutionary biologists even today. Now, an international team of researchers has teased apart a scientific debate concerning the evolutionary theories of Darwin and the Japanese geneticist Kimura. Their conclusion: the debate is unnecessarily convoluted by the co-existence of different interpretations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists discover a new phase of high-density, ultra-hot ice
description: The outer planets of our solar system, Uranus and Neptune, are water-rich gas giants. These planets have extreme pressures 2 million times the Earth's atmosphere. They also have interiors as hot as the surface of the sun. Under these conditions, water exhibits exotic, high-density ice phases.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Speeding up creation of quantum entanglement
description: A team of researchers has found a way to speed up the creation of quantum entanglement, a mystifying property of quantum mechanics that Albert Einstein once described as "spooky action at a distance."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study on movement patterns of leaf frogs in Brazil could open a path for conservation strategies
description: For researchers and environmentalists, knowing how frogs and other amphibians move through their environment is an important part of the ability to appropriately target conservation efforts. Movement is a crucial part of the relationship a species has with its environment, and disruptions in amphibian environments can take a toll on populations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Large-scale bent radio jet detected in galaxy cluster Abell 514
description: Astronomers have conducted deep low-frequency radio observations of the galaxy cluster Abell 514, using the upgraded Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope (uGMRT). In their results, they detected a large-scale bent radio jet in this cluster. The finding is reported in a paper published October 2 on the pre-print server arXiv.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Landslide triggered by heavy rain kills 27 in Cameroon
description: At least 27 people have been killed after heavy rains caused a section of a hillside covered in precariously built houses to collapse in Cameroon's capital Yaounde.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Evolutionary history of three-finger snake toxins decoded
description: Snakebites cause around 100,000 deaths worldwide every year. Researchers at the Technical University of Munich (TUM) have investigated how the toxin emerged between 50 and 120 million years ago through the modification of a gene that also occurs in mammals and other reptiles. The results could help with the development of better snakebite treatments and lead to new knowledge for the treatment of illnesses such as type 2 diabetes and hypertension.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Forest biodiversity: Mixed forests are more productive when they are structurally complex
description: The richer forests are in different tree species, the faster the trees grow and the more CO2 they can absorb. A joint study by TU Dresden, Leuphana University Lüneburg, Martin Luther University Halle-Wittenberg, University of Leipzig, University of Montpellier and the German Center for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) Halle-Jena-Leipzig sheds some light on the mechanisms behind this. The results have now been published in Science Advances.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists upcycle polyesters through new waste-free, scalable process
description: Researchers from Tokyo Metropolitan University have developed a new chemical process which upcycles polyesters, including PET in plastic bottles, to morpholine amide, a versatile and valuable building block for synthesizing a vast range of compounds. The reaction is high yield, waste-free, does not require harmful chemicals, and is easily scalable. The team have successfully broken the, often costly, closed-loop recycling loop of plastic waste, allowing upcycling to more valuable products.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Claudia Goldin wins Nobel for work on women in the labor market
description: The Nobel prize in economics was on Monday awarded to American economist Claudia Goldin for her research that has helped understand the role of women in the labor market.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Injured tortoises make slow recovery from Greece fires
description: In an animal shelter near Athens, veterinarian Kleopatra Gkika gently smears soothing cream on the leg of a tortoise, one of hundreds singed in Greece's devastating summer wildfires.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: World can't 'unplug' existing energy system: COP28 head
description: The president of the upcoming COP28 climate talks in Dubai called on Sunday for governments to abandon "fantasies" such as hastily ditching existing energy infrastructure in pursuit of climate goals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Typhoon Koinu skirts Hong Kong, heads for southern China's Hainan island
description: Typhoon Koinu tracked towards China's resort island of Hainan on Sunday night after skirting Hong Kong, bringing heavy rains and powerful gusts while prompting the closure of transport services and schools in the financial hub.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Economics prize closes out 2023 Nobel season
description: The economics prize closes the prestigious Nobel awards season on Monday, with specialists on credit, the job market or inequalities expected to be among the contenders.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers identify largest ever solar storm in ancient 14,300-year-old tree rings
description: An international team of scientists have discovered a huge spike in radiocarbon levels 14,300 years ago by analyzing ancient tree-rings found in the French Alps.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
